matcher.options: Idle - Waiting for something to happen
Iowait - Waiting for I/O to complete
Nice - Niced processes executing in user mode
Steal - Time spent in other operating systems when running in a virtualized environment
System - Processes executing in kernel mode
User - Normal processes executing in user mode

targets.expr: sum by(instance) (irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{job=~"^($node)$", mode="system"}[$__rate_interval])) / on(instance) group_left sum by (instance)((irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{job=~"^($node)$"}[$__rate_interval])))
targets.legendFormat: System - Processes executing in kernel mode

targets.expr: sum by(instance) (irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{job=~"^($node)$", mode="user"}[$__rate_interval])) / on(instance) group_left sum by (instance)((irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{job=~"^($node)$"}[$__rate_interval])))
targets.legendFormat: User - Normal processes executing in user mode

targets.expr: sum by(instance) (irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{job=~"^($node)$", mode="nice"}[$__rate_interval])) / on(instance) group_left sum by (instance)((irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{job=~"^($node)$"}[$__rate_interval])))
targets.legendFormat: Nice - Niced processes executing in user mode

targets.expr: sum by(instance) (irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{job=~"^($node)$", mode="iowait"}[$__rate_interval])) / on(instance) group_left sum by (instance)((irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{job=~"^($node)$"}[$__rate_interval])))
targets.legendFormat: Iowait - Waiting for I/O to complete

targets.expr: sum by(instance) (irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{job=~"^($node)$", mode="irq"}[$__rate_interval])) / on(instance) group_left sum by (instance)((irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{job=~"^($node)$"}[$__rate_interval])))

sum by(instance) (irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{job=~"^($node)$", mode="softirq"}[$__rate_interval])) / on(instance) group_left sum by (instance)((irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{job=~"^($node)$"}[$__rate_interval])))

sum by(instance) (irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{job=~"^($node)$", mode="steal"}[$__rate_interval])) / on(instance) group_left sum by (instance)((irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{job=~"^($node)$"}[$__rate_interval])))
targets.legendFormat: Steal - Time spent in other operating systems when running in a virtualized environment

targets.expr: sum by(instance) (irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{job=~"^($node)$", mode="idle"}[$__rate_interval])) / on(instance) group_left sum by (instance)((irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{job=~"^($node)$"}[$__rate_interval])))
targets.legendFormat: Idle - Waiting for something to happen

matcher.options: Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

targets.legendFormat: Apps - Memory used by user-space applications
PageTables - Memory used to map between virtual and physical memory addresses
SwapCache - Memory that keeps track of pages that have been fetched from swap but not yet been modified
Slab - Memory used by the kernel to cache data structures for its own use (caches like inode, dentry, etc)
Cache - Parked file data (file content) cache
Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

targets.expr:
# Select Pods with hostNetwork: false.
kube_pod_info{host_network="false", pod=~"rabbitmq-.*"}
* on(pod)
# Sum data rate for all interfaces in the Pod.
sum by(pod) (rate(container_network_receive_bytes_total{pod=~"rabbitmq-.*"}[$__rate_interval]))

# Select Pods with hostNetwork: false.
kube_pod_info{host_network="false", pod=~"rabbitmq-.*"}
* on(pod)
# Sum data rate for all interfaces in the Pod.
sum by(pod) (rate(container_network_transmit_bytes_total{pod=~"rabbitmq-.*"}[$__rate_interval]))

panels.description:
This metric is reported for the partition where the RabbitMQ data directory is stored.

If the value is zero or less, the disk alarm will be triggered and all publishing connections across all cluster nodes will be blocked.

This value can temporarily go negative because the free disk space alarm is triggered with a slight delay.

* [Alarms](https://www.rabbitmq.com/alarms.html)
* [Disk Space Alarms](https://www.rabbitmq.com/disk-alarms.html)
* [Disk Space](https://www.rabbitmq.com/production-checklist.html#resource-limits-disk-space)
* [Persistence Configuration](https://www.rabbitmq.com/persistence-conf.html)
* [Blocked Connection Notifications](https://www.rabbitmq.com/connection-blocked.html)
panels.title: Disk space available before publishers blocked

panels.description:
If the value is zero or less, the memory alarm will be triggered and all publishing connections across all cluster nodes will be blocked.

This value can temporarily go negative because the memory alarm is triggered with a slight delay.

The kernel's view of the amount of memory used by the node can differ from what the node itself can observe. This means that this value can be negative for a sustained period of time.

By default nodes use resident set size (RSS) to compute how much memory they use. This strategy can be changed (see the guides below).

* [Alarms](https://www.rabbitmq.com/alarms.html)
* [Memory Alarms](https://www.rabbitmq.com/memory.html)
* [Reasoning About Memory Use](https://www.rabbitmq.com/memory-use.html)
* [Blocked Connection Notifications](https://www.rabbitmq.com/connection-blocked.html)
panels.title: Memory available before publishers blocked

panels.description:
When this value reaches zero, new connections will not be accepted.

Client libraries, peer nodes and CLI tools will not be able to connect when the node runs out of available file descriptors.

* [Networking and RabbitMQ](https://www.rabbitmq.com/networking.html)
panels.title: TCP sockets available

panels.description:
When this value reaches zero, new connections will not be accepted and disk write operations may fail.

Client libraries, peer nodes and CLI tools will not be able to connect when the node runs out of available file descriptors.

* [Open File Handles Limit](https://www.rabbitmq.com/production-checklist.html#resource-limits-file-handle-limit)
panels.title: File descriptors available

panels.description:
Total number of ready messages ready to be delivered to consumers.

Aim to keep this value as low as possible. RabbitMQ behaves best when messages are flowing through it. It's OK for publishers to occasionally outpace consumers, but the expectation is that consumers will eventually process all ready messages.

If this metric keeps increasing, your system will eventually run out of memory and/or disk space. Consider using TTL or Queue Length Limit to prevent unbounded message growth.

* [Queues](https://www.rabbitmq.com/queues.html)
* [Consumers](https://www.rabbitmq.com/consumers.html)
* [Queue Length Limit](https://www.rabbitmq.com/maxlength.html)
* [Time-To-Live and Expiration](https://www.rabbitmq.com/ttl.html)
panels.title: Messages ready to be delivered to consumers

panels.description:
The total number of messages that are either in-flight to consumers, currently being processed by consumers or simply waiting for the consumer acknowledgements to be processed by the queue. Until the queue processes the message acknowledgement, the message will remain unacknowledged.

* [Queues](https://www.rabbitmq.com/queues.html)
* [Confirms and Acknowledgements](https://www.rabbitmq.com/confirms.html)
* [Consumer Prefetch](https://www.rabbitmq.com/consumer-prefetch.html)
panels.title: Messages pending consumer acknowledgement
